trid.file_type: file seems to be plain text/ASCII

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs
Detects potentially suspicious keywords that could indicate the use of a PowerShell exploitation framework
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Perez Diego (@darkquassar), Tuan Le (NCSGroup)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Powershell script loading obfuscated .NET Koi module
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Sekoia.io

threat_severity.level_description: Severity MEDIUM because it was considered trojan.

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET MALWARE Win32/Koi Stealer CnC Checkin (POST) M1
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET MALWARE Win32/Koi Stealer CnC Checkin (POST) M1"; flow:established,to_server; urilen:65; http.method; content:"GET"; http.uri; content:"/index.php?id="; startswith; fast_pattern; content:"&subid="; distance:36; within:7; pcre:"/^\/index\.php\?id=[a-f0-9]{8}-([a-f0-9]{4}-){3}[a-f0-9]{12}\&subid=[a-zA-Z0-9]{8}$/"; http.header_names; content:"|0d 0a|Host|0d 0a|Connection|0d 0a 0d 0a|"; bsize:22; reference:md5,ef24aa4c496b5d9803e7e37ae0f8e649; classtype:trojan-activity; sid:2049816; rev:1; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, affected_product Windows_11, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2023_12_21, deployment Perimeter, malware_family Win32_Koi, performance_impact Moderate, confidence High, signature_severity Major, updated_at 2024_01_02, reviewed_at 2024_10_03; target:src_ip;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp any any -> any $HTTP_PORTS ( msg:"POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt"; flow:to_server,established; http_header; content:"Host:",fast_pattern,nocase; pcre:"/^Host\x3a\s*(?:(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\.){3}(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\s*:?\s*\d*\s*$/ims"; service:http; reference:url,www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec15.html; classtype:policy-violation; sid:50447; rev:1; )
alert ( gid:119; sid:279; rev:1; msg:"(http_inspect) invalid status line"; metadata: rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The PowerShell script begins by defining a byte array `$binary` containing hexadecimal values.  It then retrieves a GUID from the registry (`HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography\MachineGuid`) and uses it to construct a URL.  A web request is made to this URL (`http://5.255.101.148/index.php?id=$guid&subid=e7r71tdd`), downloading a string which is split into an array `$config` using the '|' delimiter. The first element of `$config` is assigned to variable `$k`.

A loop then iterates through `$binary`, XORing each byte with a byte from `$k`, using a modulo operation to handle cases where `$k` is shorter than `$binary`. This is a simple XOR-based obfuscation technique applied to the `$binary` array. The resulting modified `$binary` is then used to load an assembly via `[System.Reflection.Assembly]::Load($binary)`. The entry point of the loaded assembly is retrieved and invoked with three arguments taken from elements [1], [2], and [3] of the `$config` array, cast as strings.
